It may be useful to do a little debugging to see what's going on:

If you=
 input all zeros to the substrate input layer, what happens at the hidden l=
ayer?  If there are no bias values, and the hidden layer computes unsigned =
sigmoids (i.e. sigmoids that range between 0 and 1), then every sigmoid in =
the hidden layer should output 0.5 (since they all have zero activation com=
ing on).  If that is not the case, then there is something else at play.

T=
hen you can check what the output nodes are generating from there.  For exa=
mple, look at a single output node and the 81 or so inputs that go into it,=
 and compute for yourself the correct output based on the weights and the a=
ctivations going over them (which would all be 0.5).

You may then find out=
 why it is saturating.  Or you may find a bug.   But it can help to isolate=
 the problem.

You can also try manipulating the substrate weights by hand =
to isolate the issue.  For example, you can set all of the hidden-layer-to-=
output weights to zero except those going into a single one of the output n=
odes.  In that case, only that node should have a unique output value.  If =
that does not happen, then you may isolate what went wrong.

ken

--- In ne=
at@yahoogroups.com, "Andrei" <andrei.rusu@...> wrote:
>
> I am using a 3 la=
yered sandwich substrate with biases, each layer 9x9 nodes, generated by a =
CPPN with sigmoid outputs. The weights are computed in exactly the same fas=
hion as in the checkers experiment,
> with a formula like: (w-0.2)/0.8 * 3.=
0 for positive weights w > 0.2 (etc) 
> 
> The output is all 1's, and the s=
ubstrate does indeed seem to have more positive weighted links than negativ=
e ones. I am facing the same 'issue' in later generations. 
> 
> The substr=
ate inputs are all between -1 and 1, but I do not normalize the 9x9 input m=
atrix. Might this be the issue. 
> 
> I changed the formulas to something l=
ike: (w-0.2)/0.8 * 0.01 and now I get values around 0.44 on all output node=
s.
> 
> Does this 'issue' suggest any misuse of (Hyper)NEAT to anyone?
> 
>=
 Thanks, 
> Andrei
>
